awd_titl_txt: Structural evolution of the Atacama fault system, northern Chile:  Insights into rheology and strain in a magmatic arc during oblique convergence
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the displacement history and mechanical behavior of the Atacama fault system -- a major tectonic structure that cuts along the Early Cretaceous magmatic arc in the Coastal Cordillera of northern Chile.  Intra-arc structures such as the Atacama fault system play a critical role in accommodating plate motion at convergent boundaries, yet significant uncertainty remains surrounding their development.  Societal benefits of the research include the development of a new collaboration between geoscience faculty and undergraduate/graduate students from Colorado State University and Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile.  Ten students from Colorado State University and Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile are participating in a joint field-mapping program that comprises a foundation for the research and provides a high-impact learning experience for the students.  Funding for this project contributes to broadening of participation of underrepresented groups in an important Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) discipline by providing support a female doctoral student from Colorado State University. The funding also supports the research program of an early-career principal investigator.  The research provides a new framework for understanding economic copper-iron-gold deposits located along the Atacama fault system, and the results will be presented by a field trip that targets the Atacama mining community.

The main scientific goals of this project are to: a) determine the timing, magnitude, and rate of slip across the Atacama fault system, b) determine the spatial and temporal relationship between magmatism and deformation along the Atacama fault system, and c) determine the rheology and deformation conditions near the brittle-plastic transition along the Atacama fault system.  Reconstructing the slip histories of major geologic structures such as the Atacama fault system is essential for understanding how oblique convergence is partitioned above subduction zones, and information on fault zone rheology and the relationship between magmatism and deformation is needed to understand how and why strain localizes in the overriding plate.  The Atacama fault system is one of the most important Andean Mesozoic structures, and it played a major role in controlling economic metal deposits.  Despite its significance, the tectonic development of the Atacama fault system is poorly understood due to the lack of detailed geologic mapping and geochronology in the region.  During their preliminary fieldwork the project researchers discovered distinct offset markers and numerous pre-, syn-, and post-kinematic igneous units that offer great potential for addressing the magnitude, timing, and rate of slip.  They also identified evidence for widespread brittle-plastic deformation, allowing them to evaluate the rheology and peak strength of the fault system.  In addition to establishing critical constraints on the Mesozoic tectonic evolution of the central Andean margin, this research will provide important insight into how oblique convergence is accommodated within magmatic arcs.  To address the proposal objectives, the research team is using a multidisciplinary research approach that includes geologic mapping, U-Pb geochronology, 40Ar/39Ar and (U-Th)/He thermochronology, microstructural analysis, electron backscatter diffraction, Ti-in-quartz and oxygen isotope geothermometry, and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy.  This research is being carried out in collaboration with Chilean geologists from Pontificia Universidad Catolica de Chile, who are playing a major role in field mapping and structural data analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project addresses the geological development of the Atacama fault system (AFS), which is a major (~1,000-km long) structure in northern Chile that records oblique convergence between tectonic plates in the Cretaceous period. The AFS is considered a classic example of a strike-slip system that localized within a magmatic arc (a linear chain of volcanoes and magmatic centers above a subduction zone). Intra-arc strike-slip faults commonly play a critical role in accommodating oblique plate convergence, yet our understanding of how and why strike-slip deformation localizes within arcs is hindered by uncertainty surrounding their deformation histories, strength, and relationship to magmatism.

The main research goals of this project were to: a) determine the timing, magnitude, and rate of displacement across the AFS, b) determine the spatial and temporal relationship between magmatism and deformation along the AFS, and c) determine the deformation conditions and strength of the AFS near the brittle-ductile transition. Through a major field mapping effort, geo/thermochronology, and microstructural analysis we have established the deformation history of this structure, constraining the timing of deformation and identifying the first clear geologic offset markers along the fault, and we have documented in detail the how magmatism is intimately related to the timing and strength of the AFS. Our work demonstrates that the AFS near Taltal, Chile (~25–26°S) consists of two major fault strands that cumulatively record ~54±6 km of left-lateral displacement between 133–110 Ma, indicating that most of the trench-parallel component of plate motion was not accommodated within the magmatic arc. Ductile (mylonitic) shearing along the AFS is restricted to areas within and surrounding ~133–119 Ma plutons that were emplaced during shear. Elevated geothermal gradients associated with these plutons and fluid-rock interactions weakened parts of the AFS, resulting in heterogeneous fault strength and a segmented fault system. Displacement on the AFS ended ~110 Ma as the magmatic arc migrated eastward and plate convergence likely became less oblique. In addition to our research on the AFS, this research has provided new insight into the pre- and post-AFS deformation history in the region. For example, we document a Middle Jurassic (~169 Ma) shear zone that records left-lateral displacement similar to the younger AFS, which has important implications for tectonic plate configurations during the early stages of the Andean orogeny. We also document the timing, magnitude, and kinematics of the NW-striking, left-lateral Taltal fault system, which initiated near the end of activity on the AFS. The Taltal fault system records E-W shortening along faults that reactivated inherited crustal weak zones, recording an important shift in subduction dynamics.

Broader Impacts

The AFS locally hosts major copper deposits, and it continues to be an active target of minerals exploration. Our 1:25,000-scale geologic mapping along a 70 km-long segment of the AFS and reconstruction of its displacement history (including the first documented displacement estimates) have direct applications for minerals exploration in this region.     

This project supported an early career PI (Singleton), two PhD students (Nikki Seymour and Skyler Mavor) and partially supported one MS student (Emily Perman) and one undergraduate student (Micah Hernandez). Through this grant we also received 12 months of funding through the NSF INTERN program to support PhD student Mavor in an internship with the U.S. Geological Survey in Flagstaff, Arizona (where he is currently employed as a research geologist). This internship provided Mavor with a variety of hands-on research experiences under the mentorship of several USGS geologists, and he led a project that investigated the tectonic transition from crustal extension to ≤10 Ma distributed right-lateral faulting in the lower Colorado River region in California and Arizona.

An important component of this project was to engage in meaningful international collaboration and cross-cultural exchange between students and faculty from Colorado State University (CSU) and Chilean geologists at Pontificia Universidad Católica (PUC), who initially met during the reconnaissance phase of this project in 2016. Our Chilean collaborators/friends (Gloria Arancibia, Rodrigo Gomila, and Gert Heuser) spent several field seasons interacting with 5 different CSU students and PI Singleton. They have made significant contributions to this work and continue to be engaged as co-authors on papers and as collaborators on new research projects.
